results.title: ‘We’re Clearly Not Doing Enough’: Drop in Testing Hampers Coronavirus Response
results.abstract: For the first time during the pandemic, the United States saw a downward trend in the number of coronavirus tests conducted each day.
results.byline: By Sarah Mervosh, Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Sheryl Gay Stolberg

results.title: As Colleges Move Classes Online, Families Rebel Against the Cost
results.abstract: Schools face rising demands for tuition rebates, increased aid and leaves of absence as students ask if college is becoming “glorified Skype.”

results.title: Coronavirus Live Updates: In Arizona, a School District Cancels Classes After Teacher ‘Sick Out’
results.abstract: Mitt Romney blasts President Trump’s handling of pandemic. Many U.S. cities fear a public transit “death spiral.” Brazil’s extensive outbreak makes it a good vaccine testing ground.

results.title: Coronavirus Crisis Has Made Brazil an Ideal Vaccine Laboratory
results.abstract: Widespread contagion, a deep bench of scientists and a robust vaccine-making infrastructure have made Brazil an important player in the quest to find a vaccine.
results.byline: By Manuela Andreoni and Ernesto Londoño

results.title: Mothers, Babies Stranded in Ukraine Surrogacy Industry
results.abstract: Virus travel bans are wreaking havoc on surrogacy agencies that help same-sex couples build families.

results.title: Postal Crisis Ripples Across Nation as Election Looms
results.abstract: President Trump’s furious objection to mail-in balloting and a new Trump-allied postmaster general are raising fears about the election and the Postal Service.
results.byline: By Luke Broadwater, Jack Healy, Michael D. Shear and Hailey Fuchs

results.title: Kamala Harris, Daughter of Immigrants, Is the Face of America’s Demographic Shift
results.abstract: Her parents’ arrival to Berkeley as young graduate students was the beginning of a historic wave of immigration from outside Europe that would change the United States in ways its leaders never imagined.

results.title: Shifting Dynamics of the Mideast Pushed Israel and U.A.E. Together
results.abstract: Prime Minister Netanyahu’s quest to open relations with Arab countries without settling the Palestinian conflict long seemed quixotic. External events changed the equation.
results.byline: By David M. Halbfinger and Ronen Bergman

results.title: The Cop Was the Hero in One Viral Video. Another Told a Different Story.
results.abstract: Bobby White was celebrated as the “Basketball Cop” after millions saw a video of him shooting hoops with local teenagers. A recording from two years earlier shows him throwing a young Black man on the hood of his car during an arrest.

results.title: 11 of Our Best Weekend Reads
results.abstract: Black activists in Chicago. Retail in Manhattan. An elephant’s pandemic journey. Bike shorts. And more.

results.title: Episode Four: ‘Here’s Another Fun Thing You Can Do’
results.abstract: Is it possible to limit the power of white parents?

results.title: A Conversation About Vice-Presidential Nominee Kamala Harris
results.abstract: Our reporters give you the back story and breakdown what this means for the election.

results.title: Biden Dreams of Kamelot
results.abstract: Trumpworld dismisses Harris as calculating. But we need a woman who can calculate a way out of the mess this president has made.

results.title: The 19th Amendment: An Important Milestone in an Unfinished Journey
results.abstract: A century later, it’s past time to recognize the women of color who were sidelined in the fight for gender and racial equality.

results.title: The Week QAnon Went Mainstream
results.abstract: A supporter of the dangerous conspiracy theory is most likely headed to Congress. The social media platforms have some soul-searching to do.

results.title: Learning to Love Joe Biden
results.abstract: He’s not out on the campaign trail now, but when he was a young man in a hurry, he told us who he was.

results.title: The British Monarchy Is a Game. Harry and Meghan Didn’t Want to Play.
results.abstract: Prince Harry confused sacrifice with service. Meghan, Duchess of Sussex, confused it with fame.

results.title: The Improbable Journey of the Suffragist Sash
results.abstract: How a strip of fabric went from iconic protest accessory to pageant queen prop to bachelorette party wear.

results.abstract: For some, the senator’s being on the Democratic ticket is about more than just the vice presidency.

results.title: Is Gaming the Future of the Virtual World?
results.abstract: During the pandemic, digital three-dimensional environments are where much of life is taking place.

results.title: The Undertold, Undersold Story of Kamala Harris
results.abstract: As a prosecutor she can make you tremble. But as a trailblazer can she make you cry?

results.title: The Unlikely Triumph of Italian Nationhood
results.abstract: Italy coheres as America breaks apart.

results.title: Set Parents Free
results.abstract: Everyone is terrified of both sickness and censure. Are there better ways to raise our children amid a pandemic?

results.title: ‘We’ve Already Survived an Apocalypse’: Indigenous Writers Are Changing Sci-Fi
results.abstract: Long underrepresented in genre fiction, Native American and First Nations authors are reshaping its otherworldly (but still often Eurocentric) worlds.

results.title: 15 Creative Women for Our Time
results.abstract: Whether in the realm of art or design, food or fashion, these talents have stayed true to themselves and, in doing so, have pushed the boundaries of their respective fields.

results.title: The Particular Texture and Joy of Homemade Ice Cream
results.abstract: The moments spent watching and waiting for this chocolate-flake raspberry ice cream to form capture a childish delight that we could all use right now.

results.title: Under Siege in Belarus, Lukashenko Turns to Putin
results.abstract: The shift toward Russia comes at a time of crisis for President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus, who has frequently played Moscow off against the West.

results.title: Polish Cleric Retires in Face of Cover-Up Accusations. It’s Not Enough, Critics Say.
results.abstract: Pope Francis accepted the resignation of Archbishop Slawoj Leszek Glodz of Poland, a move seen as a subtle rebuke. But far more is needed to address the abuse of children by priests, advocates say.
results.byline: By Elisabetta Povoledo and Anatol Magdziarz

results.title: Trump Ads Attack Biden Through Deceptive Editing and Hyperbole
results.abstract: We reviewed all of the Trump campaign’s television ads since June. Two-thirds contained clearly misleading claims or videos.

results.title: Pinterest Employees Demand Gender and Race Equality
results.abstract: More than 200 said they stood in solidarity with three former co-workers who have accused the company of discrimination.

results.title: Japanese Politicians Mark War Anniversary at Contentious Shrine
results.abstract: Shinjiro Koizumi, a rising political star, was one of four cabinet ministers who went to Yasukuni Shrine, which has strong links to Japan’s imperial past.

results.title: ‘The Fish Rots From the Head’: How a Salmon Crisis Stoked Russian Protests
results.abstract: Plentiful salmon used to be one of the few perks for residents of Russia’s Far East. Then the fish vanished, and many local residents blamed President Putin.
results.byline: By Anton Troianovski and Sergey Ponomarev

results.title: A Bitter Wind at a Shaky Time, and Iowa Is Left Reeling
results.abstract: Devastating windstorms just before harvest were the last thing that Iowa farmers needed.

results.title: America’s Retirement Race Gap, and Ideas for Closing It
results.abstract: Scholars and policymakers have proposed ways to fix the inequities between whites and people of color, including changes to Social Security and building wealth from birth.

results.title: Bayern 8, Barcelona 2. The End.
results.abstract: A thrashing in the Champions League quarterfinals showed Bayern Munich at the peak of its powers and Barcelona at the end of the line.

results.abstract: Four ways to air-condition your home more efficiently in the summer heat.

results.abstract: No one likes to make mistakes, but how you manage them can be a key to a stronger future.

results.abstract: All those “Good jobs!” might be undermining kids’ independence and self-confidence.

results.abstract: Play can feel silly, unproductive and time consuming. And that’s precisely the point.

results.title: Cracking Codes With Sanford Biggers
results.abstract: “You don’t have to follow the norms,” says this artist who makes wrenching sculptures transformed by gunfire and radically altered heirloom quilts. A studio visit sheds light on his personal journey.

results.title: Taking the Edinburgh Fringe’s Madcap Energy Online
results.abstract: For the first time in its 73-year history, the hugely influential festival is canceled. Devoted fans and theater makers are finding ways to keep the spirit alive.

results.title: Tackling a Century-Old Mystery: Did My Grandmother Vote?
results.abstract: Had she, in the throes of segregation and suffrage, cast a hard-won vote? I needed to know.

results.title: Kingston: A City Remade by the Coronavirus
results.abstract: A writer who moved upstate for a slower lifestyle fears that the latest wave of migrants, fleeing Covid, will bring their worst instincts with them.

results.title: How Do You Solve a Moon Mystery? Fire a Laser at It
results.abstract: Researchers have used reflective prisms left on the moon’s surface for decades, but had increasingly seen problems with their effectiveness.

results.title: This Star Looked Like It Would Explode. Maybe It Just Sneezed
results.abstract: The mysterious dimming of the red supergiant Betelgeuse is the result of a stellar exhalation, astronomers say.

results.title: A Honeybee’s Tongue Is More Swiss Army Knife Than Ladle
results.abstract: Once again, insects prove to be more complicated than scientists thought they were.

results.title: The Coronavirus Is New, but Your Immune System Might Still Recognize It
results.abstract: Some people carry immune cells called T cells that can capitalize on the virus’s resemblance to other members of its family tree.
